sources.title: White Tiger (1923) Crime, Drama, Mystery, Silent Film
sources.description:
Three crooks pull off a magnificent crime. As they're forced to hide out together they slowly begin to distrust each other.

Director: Tod Browning
Writers: Tod Browning, Charles Kenyon
Stars: Priscilla Dean, Matt Moore, Raymond Griffith

sources.title: White Tiger (1923) | Colorized Public Domain Silent Crime Thriller by Tod Browning
sources.description:
White Tiger (1923) is a silent crime drama directed by Tod Browning, the filmmaker who later created Dracula (1931) and Freaks (1932). This restored and colorized public domain classic brings back an early thriller that combines mystery, gangsters, and mechanical illusions, showcasing Browningâ€™s fascination with deception and criminal psychology. Featuring stars Priscilla Dean, Wallace Beery, Raymond Griffith, and Matt Moore, the film blends suspense with early cinematic tricks, making it a fascinating look at crime drama in the silent era.

Plot Summary:
The story follows a gang of international criminals led by Sylvia (Priscilla Dean), a woman entangled in a world of deception and betrayal. Partnered with the sinister gangster Harvey (Wallace Beery) and the clever con man Roy (Raymond Griffith), Sylvia becomes involved in a scheme centered around a mechanical chess-playing automaton used to commit robbery and fraud.

Their plot unfolds in a gloomy European setting, where crime, disguise, and betrayal are the tools of survival. When an American adventurer, Dick Longworth (Matt Moore), crosses paths with Sylvia, he becomes both her love interest and her potential savior. As double-crosses mount and loyalties collapse, Sylvia must decide between loyalty to her criminal partners and a chance at redemption.

The climax reveals Browningâ€™s signature fascination with trickery and mechanical illusions, elements he would perfect in later works.

Cast and Crew:
â€¢ Director: Tod Browning
â€¢ Writer: Tod Browning (story), Joseph Farnham (titles)
â€¢ Cinematography: William Fildew

Starring:
â€¢ Priscilla Dean as Sylvia
â€¢ Wallace Beery as Harvey
â€¢ Raymond Griffith as Roy
â€¢ Matt Moore as Dick Longworth
â€¢ John Davidson as The Hindu

Film Significance:
White Tiger is notable for showcasing Tod Browningâ€™s recurring themes of crime, illusion, and betrayal, which would later define his best-known films. The mechanical chess automaton is a centerpiece of the story, symbolizing both deception and the blending of stage illusion with cinema.

Priscilla Dean, one of Universalâ€™s biggest silent stars of the early 1920s, gives a powerful performance as a conflicted woman caught between crime and conscience. Wallace Beery, who would later become an MGM star and Academy Award winner, appears here in one of his many villainous early roles. The filmâ€™s atmosphere, suspense, and use of trick effects make it a fascinating silent thriller that foreshadows Browningâ€™s later Gothic masterpieces.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
This film is in the public domain, which means it is completely free of copyright restrictions and can be legally shared, viewed, studied, and preserved without limitation. Colorized Public Domain restores and enhances these historic works through careful digital cleaning, visual restoration, and colorization techniques. Our mission is to ensure that timeless classics like White Tiger remain available to a worldwide audience. By presenting them in color and modern quality, we make them more engaging and accessible to younger generations who might otherwise overlook black-and-white cinema. This process respects the original film while providing a new layer of appreciation for todayâ€™s viewers.

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
The original 1923 release was silent and black and white, relying on intertitles and early effects to tell its story. While authentic, many modern audiences overlook silent black-and-white films. By restoring and colorizing this edition, we bring out the suspense, atmosphere, and visual richness of Tod Browningâ€™s early crime drama. This approach makes the film more immersive for todayâ€™s audiences while preserving its historical significance.

metadata.Plot: Sylvia Donovan, Roy Donovan, and "Count Donelli" are three international crooks who come to America. Sylvia and Roy are unaware that they are brother and sister. The three cooperate to rob wealthy homes by using a gimmick known as a chess-playing machine. Eventually, Sylvia and Roy learn that they are brother and sister and that "Count Donelli," alias Hawkes, killed their father. The detective and Sylvia fall in love.
metadata.Actors: Priscilla Dean, Matt Moore, Raymond Griffith
